overview.short: Rhizobium radiobacter is a Gram-negative, aerobic, motile rod historically classified as Agrobacterium radiobacter.
overview.clinical_context: Occasionally associated with opportunistic infections, particularly catheter-related or device-associated infections.

species_markers.notes: Urease positivity helps separate R. radiobacter from some other Rhizobium species.
R. radiobacter is more commonly reported in clinical specimens compared to other Rhizobium species.

common_confusions.reason: Former taxonomic classification; older systems may still report Agrobacterium radiobacter.
Shared aerobic oxidase-positive phenotype with overlapping biochemical reactions.
Environmental oxidase-positive rods can overlap phenotypically.

when_to_question_identification: Oxidase negativity suggests Enterobacterales or other genera.
Strong carbohydrate fermentation profile suggests misidentification.
Anaerobic growth argues against Rhizobium radiobacter.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Most reliable routine method to distinguish R. radiobacter from related genera.
Useful for resolving historical Agrobacterium/Rhizobium classification issues.
